an3.32:4.1: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
an3.32:4.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
an3.32:5.1: “Could it be, sir, that a mendicant might gain a state of samādhi such that there’s no ego, possessiveness, or tendency to conceit for this conscious body; and no ego, possessiveness, or tendency to conceit for all external stimuli;
an3.32:5.2: and that they’d live having attained the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where ego, possessiveness, and tendency to conceit are no more?”
an3.32:5.3: “It could be, Ānanda, that a mendicant gains a state of samādhi such that they have no ego, possessiveness, or tendency to conceit for this conscious body; and no ego, possessiveness, or tendency to conceit for all external stimuli;
an3.32:5.4: and that they’d live having attained the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where ego, possessiveness, and tendency to conceit are no more.”
an3.32:7.2: ‘This is peaceful; this is sublime—that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.’
an3.32:7.3: That’s how, Ānanda, a mendicant might gain a state of samādhi such that there’s no ego, possessiveness, or tendency to conceit for this conscious body; and no ego, possessiveness, or tendency to conceit for all external stimuli;
an3.32:7.4: and that they’d live having achieved the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where ego, possessiveness, and tendency to conceit are no more.
an3.32:8.1: And Ānanda, this is what I was referring to in ‘The Way to the Beyond’, in ‘The Questions of Puṇṇaka’ when I said:
an3.32:9.1: ‘Having considered the world high and low,
an3.32:9.2: they’re not shaken by anything in the world.
an3.32:9.3: Peaceful, unclouded, untroubled, with no need for hope—
an3.32:9.4: They’ve crossed over birth and old age, I declare.’”
